title: Scene 1 - fleeing the crossroads towards the Docks
where_when:
as the crossroads fade into memory you arrive at the North part of Island. 

its mid morning, Grey, windy and cold  and you have arrived at the marina
text:
You emerge from the path into the north end of town.the air feel's wrong, like the world’s holding its muggy breath. to the left you see a nearly empty marina. Only one ship remains, a ragged crew scrambling across its deck while a large scary man bellows orders.

 to the left of you homes and Shops along the waterfront are hastily boarded, doors braced with mismatched scraps, splintered fence posts, broken crates. The air feels tight with panic.

People hurry through the streets with carts, baskets, and bags heaped with food and valuables. Some push wheelbarrows piled high; others clutch bundles over their shoulders.They all seem to be heading in the same direction as they head for the small foothills in the distance, cautious eyes dart constantly toward the sea.

You stop and mutter, “What the hell is going on?”
exit_line: I Cant help the feeling like I have been in this situation at least once before...is this.... Deja-vu?

title: heading towards the last boat in the Marina
where_when: You shove through the wind and the stink of wet rope, boots splashing through puddles that taste of iron as you run for the lone ship at the pier.
text:
The closer you get, the worse it looks, men hauling ropes with wild eyes, what looks like farmers, the men and women bound to the rail with torn fabric, children sobbing their cries rising and falling with the sound of waves slapping against the hull.
 The scary captain with an Austrian accent bellows out at you... "Come with me if you want to live", you grab the last mooring line holding the boat to the dock and swing aboard saving the captain and crew from having to cut it
exit_line: You're skeptical, but a lack of information make's this the best  option.

title: Boarding the Ship
where_when: At the ship, moments later.
text: You decide to climb aboard, ignoring the screams and confusion around you. The deck reeks of salt and fear. The captain shouts for lines to be cut as the ship lurches against its moorings.The captain you realize, is trying to save people despite his brutal demeanor. The storm builds.
exit_line: At a speed you would not have expected The ship begins to pull away from the dock. as if the very sea itself is retreating from the shore.

title: Too Late at the Docks
where_when: North docks, as the ship pulls away.
text: You step back from the rail and turn to flee, but the moorings snap like thread and the crowd surges. The sea goes silent, then rises to swallow the pier. You try to run, but salt and sky and weight crush you flat. There is no time to scream.
exit_line: Some choices only look like safety.

title: Running for the Hills
where_when: North island foothills, moments later.
text: You sprint with the crowd toward the low hills. The ground trembles. The sea goes silent behind you.
exit_line: You’ve got seconds. Pick wrong and the sea decides.

title: Too Late in the Foothills
where_when: North island foothills, moments later.
text:
You flee the madness at the docks and follow the crowd toward the small foothills. You have nothing to carry and easily overtake several people weighed down by their possessions. The ground trembles underfoot. The sound of the sea fades into an eerie silence.

Then the sky darkens. You turn your head and see it-the horizon rising, the ocean folding over itself. The wall of water races inland, swallowing rooftops and roads. What must have been moments feels like seconds. There is nowhere to go and nothing to do about it. The world is swallowed in salt and roar and cold. Your chest caves as your lungs collapse. You are gone before you can even scream.
exit_line: The sea takes everything,...the houses, the vegetation, life and even the hills.

title: Too Late
where_when: North docks
text:
Your determined to discover the Malady that could be the cause of this Panic, in the distance  The crowd runs inland. The sea goes quiet, then slowly drains, your limbs frozen at the site of it. the ocean revealing it scars and debris on its sandy underbelly 

suddenly you see it. the wall of water coming straight at you, what must have been moments feels like seconds, theres no where to go and nothing to do about it, the sky is blanketed over in salty darkness as the wave starts to crest 
.suddenly you feel your chest cave, as your lungs explode, instantly your crushed by a furious wall of cold wet Darkness.
exit_line:
Congratz!! Your story ends in Tragic fashion. 
 this is what happens when You make bad choices

title: Holding Fast - The Wave Rises
where_when: Above deck, seconds before impact.
text: The deck tilts skyward as the sea climbs the sky. You wrap your arms around the main mast while crewmen vanish into the foam. The captain’s voice cuts through the roar: "Jump!" For a heartbeat you hesitate, staring up at the wall of water folding over the ship. You can’t hold any longer. It’s jump or die.
exit_line: you have Seconds left. Pick your fate.

title: Wave-ing goodbye
where_when: The moment the crest falls.
text: You cling to the mast until your arms give out, your arms Locked in fear. The world folds and the deck erupts, as the boats slams back down to earth . your pelted with sharp debris and shrapnel from the deck exploding.your innards are introduced to new elements shredded Timber, broken iron, salt, and Pain. Your lungs never get that next breath.
exit_line: The sea does not bargain.

title: Thrown into the Deep - The Backside of the Wave
where_when: Midday becomes midnight as the wave crests overhead. The ship tilts skyward, and you leap.
text:
You jump. For a moment, it feels like flying - then everything is cold and chaos. The sound disappears, replaced by pressure and silence. You tumble through foam and wreckage, lungs on fire, the world flipping end over end.

Your shoulder hits something hard - maybe the ship’s broken mast - but it spins you just right. The back side of the wave pulls you down, then hurls you forward with terrifying speed.

When you finally break the surface, the world is gone. The ship, the dock, the city - all erased. Only floating debris and distant thunder remain.

You cling to a barrel and let the current take you. The stars vanish. The mist thickens. Somewhere ahead, faint singing cuts through the noise.
exit_line: You drift in the dark, waiting to learn whether the sea meant to kill you or spare you.

title: Below Deck - The Hold
where_when: Cargo hold, lantern light, wet boards.
text: Bodies packed tight. would be survivors have tied themselves to beams and rails. The air is sour with Urine and fear. Water starts finding the seams. this is probably not the best place to be!

choices.label: tie yourself to the beam and embrace for impact

exit_line: Stuck between a morgue and a sandbar.

title: The Broken Hold - Survivors in the Wreck
where_when: Below deck, after the wave. The broken ship is half-buried against the rocks, creaking but still intact.
text:
You wake in darkness, the sound of dripping water close to your ear. The air tastes of rot and rust. The ship didn’t sink - it split, wedged between jagged black rocks. Half the hold is flooded. The other half is a tomb of splintered beams and crushed bodies.

Someone nearby coughs. Then another voice calls out - hoarse, desperate. A handful of survivors crawl through the wreckage, gathering in the only pocket of dry space left.

You can hear the sea outside, grinding at the hull like teeth. There’s no telling how long the wreck will hold.

A narrow gap in the planks shows pale daylight above - escape..... if you dare.

choices.label: Stay below and wait for help

exit_line: The ship creaks like it’s whispering its last words.

title: No One Is Coming
where_when: Below deck, the wreck slowly filling with freezing water.
text:
As you wait for help to arrive, you feel weaker and the shivering grows more violent. The broken hull groans and shifts as icy tidal water creeps higher around your legs and waist.

You listen for voices, for boots on the deck, for anything that sounds like rescue. Nothing answers but the sea grinding at the rocks outside.

A cold, ugly truth settles in. You are on your own. No one is coming for you. Maybe it is one of life’s more valuable lessons, learned a little too late.

Your teeth stop chattering. Your hands go numb. You feel so cold, and so sleepy. Eventually you stop trying to keep your head above the water.

You slip away quietly, more tired than afraid.
exit_line: In the end, the wreck holds you tighter than any rescuer ever would.

title: The Waiting
where_when: The broken hold, water rising.
text: You glance through the porthole just in time to see the ship cresting the top of a massive wave. For a heartbeat the world hangs still. Then the ocean moves on without you, and the ship drops. The fall is several hundred feet of weightless terror before the hull slams into the sea. Your spine folds. your leg tears open to let the shattered bone out. You don’t scream. You can’t. The splintering hull groans its last as darkness and broken planks tighten around you, as the last of the light shrinks to a coin and fades. The sea has finally come to collect its trophy.
exit_line: Silence, then bubbles, then nothing.

title: Back on land — Fog, Wreckage, and Something Calling
where_when: Shattered coastline, minutes after the wreck.
text:
You claw your way out of the broken hull and drag yourself across wet sand. The world is gray and shapeless, the air heavy with mist and the stench of splintered wood. Behind you, the rest of the ship grinds against hidden rocks, dying louder than the people who were on it.

When you finally reach the drift line, you collapse. For a long moment there is only your breathing and the slow hiss of the tide.

Then you hear it.
A voice. No—several. Soft, distant, threading through the fog like a lullaby too old to remember. It rises, falls, and hangs in the air like a hook.

Far down the shoreline, beyond the rocks, fires glow where other survivors gather, shouting for help.

The choice pulls at you like two different currents.
exit_line: The fog hides both salvation and mistakes.

title: Into the Fog — The Pull of the Voices
where_when: Shoreline, fog thick as wool.
text:
You follow the singing, half convinced it's a trick of exhaustion. Your legs shake with every step. Salt burns your lips. You haven’t eaten since before the storm — maybe longer.

Still, you walk.
Not because it’s smart. Not because it’s safe. Because something in the sound won’t let you stop.

The fog parts.
Three women stand at the waterline, silhouettes framed in gray. Beautiful in a way that makes your tired brain lag a beat behind your eyes. Human enough, but wrong in ways you can’t name.

One holds a small clay cup, steam curling from it, sweet and warm. The scent hits you like a memory of better days — fruit, spice, something comforting.

Your stomach twists with hunger. Your throat feels like cracked stone. You take the cup before you even realize your hand has moved.

The liquid is warm and sharp and sweet. Relief floods your limbs. The pain dulls. The world steadies.

The tallest of the three smiles and touches your cheek. "Come," she says. "The cold will take you if you stay out here any longer."
exit_line: The fog swallows the beach behind you. Their footsteps make no sound.

title: Second Thoughts — Instinct Over Hunger
where_when: Shoreline, fog rolling in thicker than before.
text:
The sweet warmth spreads across your tongue, but something in you tightens. Maybe it’s instinct. Maybe it’s the part of your brain that hasn’t drowned yet. You lower the cup.

The tallest woman tilts her head, smile still perfect but somehow colder. The other two exchange a glance you weren’t supposed to see.

Your arms and legs are trembling with exhaustion, but you take one step back anyway. The fog curls around your ankles. Your heartbeat thumps in your ears like a warning drum.

"You’re hurt," the tallest one says. "Let us help you." Her tone stays gentle, but her eyes sharpen as if measuring how long you would last if you tried to run.

The warmth you felt a moment ago twists into something else — not fear exactly, but a deep awareness that you shouldn’t be here. Not with them. Not like this.

One of the women slowly reaches toward you with the cup again. "Please," she whispers, voice too soft to be real. "It’s only comfort."

Your breath fogs the air. The world tilts. You’re not sure if you’re about to faint or bolt.

choices.label: Give in and follow them after all
Back away and flee into the fog

exit_line: Every instinct screams to choose now, before you lose the strength to move.

title: The Survivor Camp — What’s Left of the Living
where_when: Shattered coastline, fog thinning as the storm finally drifts inland.
text:
You follow the glow of distant lanterns and shouting voices until shapes begin to form through the mist. A handful of survivors have gathered along a ridge of driftwood and broken beams, using scraps of sailcloth to block the worst of the wind.

No one looks good. Everyone is scraped raw, soaked through, or barely standing. Whatever strength kept them alive ended on the sand.

A man waves you over. His beard is full of salt and his hands shake, but he speaks with the steadiness of someone trying very hard not to fall apart.
"We lost most of the crew. Supplies are gone. If the rain stops, maybe we can get a fire going. Until then, stay close. People vanish in fog like this."

He’s not lying. Out past the camp, something moves — slow, heavy, dragging across the wet stones in a rhythm that doesn’t belong to anything you recognize. A few survivors whisper about shapes they saw crawling inland when the wave retreated.

Heat, shelter, leadership — none of that exists yet. Just cold air, wet clothes, and the uneasy feeling of being watched.

choices.label: Help the survivors reinforce the camp

exit_line: The storm has passed, but the danger hasn’t.

title: Reinforcing the Camp — Holding Back the Night
where_when: The survivor camp, fog lifting just enough to see shapes move in the distance.
text:
You step toward the cluster of survivors working along the ridge of debris. Their shelter is more wish than structure: snapped oars tied with seaweed, crooked planks wedged against each other, torn canvas flapping like a dying flag.

You join the effort. The work is mindless but grounding: hauling driftwood, wedging beams, knotting rope around anything that will hold. No one speaks much. Everyone listens.

Something out there drags across the stones again. Closer this time. Heavy.

An older woman beside you tightens her grip on a broken spar. "That isn’t the sea," she whispers, eyes locked on the fog.

A young boy starts crying quietly into his sleeve. A man tries to reassure him, but his own voice cracks halfway through.

You finish reinforcing the last section of the windbreak, driving a splintered beam deep into the wet sand. It won’t stop a wave, or a storm, or whatever is moving out there. But it might buy a few seconds if things go bad.

A shape flickers at the edge of the fog — low to the ground, wide, and too smooth in its movements to be human.

No one breathes.

choices.label: Return to the campfire circle and plan with the survivors
find a higher vantage point and scout for danger

exit_line: Something is watching. And it knows you’re here.

title: Drawing Lines in the Sand
where_when: Around the campfire, weapons and nerves wearing thin.
text:
You stay by the fire. Not because it feels safe, but because running blind into the fog feels worse.

Someone drags over a crate lid to use as a makeshift table. You lay the broken oar across it. Others add what they have: splintered planks, snapped spars, a rusted hook, half a shattered spearhead.

"We’re not scaring that thing off," you say. "So we make it bleed. Legs first. If it can’t stand, it can’t kill as many of us."

It isn’t a rousing speech, but people listen.

You show them how to sharpen the cleaner pieces of wood against stone. A few survivors take turns hardening the tips in the fire. Others break longer beams into manageable lengths and strip them down to something that might pass for a spear.

A rough plan forms in the dirt: a left flank, a right flank, and a center line around the fire. Fire bearers in the middle, spear carriers on the sides, everyone else staying behind them to drag the wounded away if things go bad.

"We go for the joints," you say, tracing circles at the base of a crude crab shape in the sand. "If it has a brain, it’s hiding under a plate. We’re not getting there unless the legs stop moving."

No one talks about winning. Just not being wiped out in the first ten seconds.

A shout cuts through the planning from higher up the wreckage. The lookout’s voice cracks halfway through the words.

"It’s coming! From the shore! Big as the camp!"

choices.label: Take your place in the line and prepare to fight

exit_line: There’s no safe direction. Just the side you choose to stand on when it reaches you.

title: Shoreline Sweep — Whispers by the Fire
where_when: A little way down the beach, near a rough campfire ring of stones and driftwood.
text:
You volunteer to work the shoreline. It sounds useful, and more importantly, it gives you a reason to keep moving.

You pick through the wreckage: smashed crates, broken spars, a few half-rotten nets. Most of it is useless. Anything that might have been food is either gone or ground into the sand.

You do find one thing worth keeping — a length of broken oar, solid enough to swing like a club. You keep it.

Closer to the waterline, you spot something else. Deep grooves in the wet sand. Not from the tide. Parallel gouges, heavy and wide, like something with weight and too many legs dragged itself up the beach.

By the time you make it back to the main camp, a rough circle has formed around a struggling fire. A few more survivors have limped in. People talk quietly, comparing what they’ve seen: shapes in the fog, scraping sounds on stone, something big moving just out of sight.

When you describe the grooves in the sand, the camp goes even quieter.

"We need eyes higher up," someone says finally. "If that thing comes back, I’d rather see it before it’s on top of us."

choices.label: Stay by the fire and help plan defenses
Volunteer to climb higher and keep watch

exit_line: Whether you stay close or climb high, everyone knows the same truth: something is out there, and it probably isn't nice.

title: High Ground — The Thing in the Fog
where_when: On a rise of broken hulls and rock above the survivor camp.
text:
You climb until your legs burn, using splintered ribs of the ship and jagged rock as handholds. From above, the beach looks like a graveyard someone tried to sweep into piles and gave up halfway.

At first you don’t see it.

Then the fog shifts.

What you thought were boulders near the tideline unfold. A shell the size of a cottage heaves up out of the mist, glistening and scarred. Long, jointed legs probe the sand, each one ending in a hooked point that digs deep and pulls the bulk of it forward.

The thing moves with awful patience, picking through wreckage. One claw the size of a wagon lifts something you decide not to look at too closely. It crushes, tests, discards.

A giant crab, dredged up by the wave from somewhere it should have stayed.

Then it pauses.

Slowly, it turns. Its legs dig in, angling its mass not toward the open sea, but inland.

Toward the survivor camp.

From up here, you can see the whole picture: the fire, the people huddled around it, and the slow inevitability of the thing closing the distance.

choices.label: Race back and help the camp stand and fight

exit_line: Running doesn’t save you out here. It just changes what kills you.

title: Last Stand in the Wreckage
where_when: Back at the camp, moments before the creature reaches the firelight.
text:
You slide and half-fall down the broken slope, lungs burning as you sprint back toward the camp.

"On your feet!" you shout, voice cracking. "It’s coming this way! Huge, claws, legs, just move!"

There’s no argument. Fear does what leadership couldn’t. People scramble for anything with weight or a point: broken oars, snapped spars, sharpened planks. A few survivors drag burning branches from the fire, turning them into makeshift torches.

The creature rises out of the fog like a moving cliff. Up close, it’s worse. Chitin ridged with old scars, barnacles like tumors, its left eye clouded and useless, the other glossy and black, reflecting firelight and panic.

It reaches the edge of the camp and hesitates, confused by the heat and shouting. You don’t give it time to decide.

You and the others surge forward in a ragged line, driving fire and splintered wood at its legs. It snaps, tears, crushes the would-be defenders on its right side, leaving what’s left of the survivors to attack its left, its blind side.

Someone lands a lucky hit in the joint of one leg. Another torch finds soft tissue near a second joint and jabs burning wood into it. The creature thrashes, missteps, and crashes to one side with a shriek that doesn’t belong on land.

That’s when you see your opening.

You climb the creature’s flat head as it struggles to right itself. You raise the broken oar and thrust it down with everything you have, aiming for the softest patch in its cranial plate. The shell cracks. You drive the oar again. And again. The crab’s movements slow, then stop completely as its claw releases a crushed survivor.

When the creature is finally still, no one cheers. The losses are obvious. The victory feels accidental, shaky, painful, and probably temporary. Someone throws more wood on the fire while others start cutting away chunks of meat.

A man speaks up, voice dry and exhausted. "We’ll bury the dead tomorrow," he says. "Tonight we need to eat."

No one argues. No one sighs. The first pieces of crab are skewered and held over the coals. Tonight, at least, there is more than enough for the people still standing. Tomorrow another nightmare could wash in from the sea.
exit_line: For now, the beach is yours. Tomorrow is a different problem.

title: The Sirens' Welcome - Salt and Sweetness
where_when: Shoreline cave, torchlight flickering on wet stone.
text:
The liquid burns like salt and honey. For a heartbeat you think you’re dying again, lungs filling with the sea. Then you cough, and breathe - the air thick, heavy, alive.

They carry you into a shallow cave carved by tides. Shells glow in the walls like trapped stars. Someone wraps your wounds with sea-silk; another hums a tune that pulls your heartbeat into rhythm.

When you wake, the three of them sit in a circle around you. Bowls of strange fruit glisten in the sand. Their eyes shine like wet coins.

'You fell from the storm,' the tallest one says. 'But storms do not choose who survives. Tell us, land-born - why did the sea spare you?'

Their smiles are gentle, but something sharp hides behind them. You can feel it - like teeth under velvet.
exit_line: Their voices blend with the tide, patient and hungry for truth.

title: Salt and Honesty
where_when: Still within the sirens' cave, somewhere between night and dawn.
text:
You are so thirsty. The liquid burns, and you keep drinking out of thirst and desperation. As soon as you drink from the conch, you wonder if you should have been more cautious.

There is an immediate sense of relief from the pain. At the same time, everything that happened overwhelms you. You break down in tears. You tell these beautiful, strange creatures everything: the crossroads, the ship at the marina, the people on the boat hoping for escape; now entangled in seaweed and smashed against the rocks. You recount the screams, the black wall of water, the terror that crawled up your spine.

The cave creatures listen without interrupting. Weariness finally stills your sobbing. The tallest siren moves closer and touches your chest, her hand cool and slick.

"No lies," she announces softly to the coven. Her eyes narrow in appraisal. "We will save you, land-born. You are the first human we have come across who held their deceitful tongue, their ego, and their lust." 

Another vessel is lifted toward your lips. This drink is colder. Sharper. It tastes like the moment just before a wave breaks. Your veins tingle. Your heartbeat begins to match the rhythm of the tide.

The water rises around your ankles. Your lungs brace for panic, but it doesn’t come. Not yet.

choices.label: Let the tide take you deeper

exit_line: You feel the pull of the deep, patient and ancient.

title: Chosen of the Deep — Becoming Something New
where_when: Beneath the cave's surface, drifting into the dark water.
text:
The water climbs your waist, your ribs, your throat. Instead of fear, there is a strange peace. Your body hums with the cold, with the lingering sweetness of the drink, with something new curling beneath your skin.

You slip beneath the surface.

Your eyes open in the dark and the dark answers. Shapes bloom where there should be nothing. You see every shell embedded in the stone, every ripple of current, every tiny creature scuttling in the silt.

Your legs feel distant—muted—then they shift. Bones soften. Skin smooths. A powerful tail unfurls where your feet should be, scaled and shimmering in the faint blue light.

You move it once, instinctively. It feels like remembering something you never learned.

Above you, the sirens glide in a slow circle, watching with something between pride and amazement.

"Breathe," the tallest one commands.

You inhale.

The sea rushes into you.

It should kill you. It doesn’t.

Your chest expands, your pulse steadies, and for the first time since the storm, you feel alive—truly alive—as if the ocean has been waiting for you all along.

You swim upward, cutting through the water like a blade. The world is new. The night is vast. And you are no longer prey.

choices.label: Accept your new life beneath the waves

exit_line: You were meant to drown tonight. Instead, you were claimed.

title: The Eaten
where_when: Inside the sirens' cave. The tide creeping higher.
text: You force a smile and tell them what you think they want to hear - a Hero's story, of slavers, chains, sword-fights and escape. The lie comes easy. Too easy. The three seductive and unnaturally beautiful creatures nod toward each other, smiling in silent agreement. They seem to believe you as one of them gently offers a new shell, winking seductively as you lift it to your lips. It is sweeter than the first. You gulp it down greedily, relieved they’ve accepted your lie. The tallest one moves closer, her expression unreadable. Her lips brush yours, tasting your mouth with her tongue. Her breath cool and sweet, like apples and vanilla orchids, and in that instant, you fall in love. Gradually the light in the cave shifts. The lust in her eyes doesn’t fade; it sharpens, glinting with the calm focus of hunger. Shadows stretch along the walls as her voice sharpens. 'Pitiful land-born,' she says. 'We can taste truth on the air.' With one graceful motion she slaps the shell from your hands. 'The drink will teach you honesty.' Your stomach twists. It burns. Your tongue goes numb. You try to stand, but your legs will not move. Paralyzed, you watch as their lovely mouths open wide, revealing rows of slick, needle sharp teeth. They close in, humming the same alluring tune that brought you here. You scream once, salt and blood fill your throat, and then you drown again, slower this time, as they tear into your limbs and torso. The water goes dark with blood and rendered flesh, the pain makes the world fold in on itself. You feel your soul tear loose and rise, breaking the surface far above. The last thing you see is your own body sinking below, motionless. Then everything turns white, and you find yourself standing once more at the crossroads, with no memory of how you got there.
exit_line: The sea keeps its secrets. You just became one of them.

title: Your Journey Ends In Success
text: Your story has reached its conclusion.
